Like Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Rep. Lewis has been a drum major for peace, for progress and we are all lucky to have a man of his caliber serving this nation in Congress.

Thankful to have the opportunity to speak with Delawareans this morning about Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the legacy he left behind.   This is such an important holiday, but not just because we have the opportunity to reflect on Dr. King's dedication to justice and equality. Dr. King was about action and right now we need action. Today, more than ever we need people with broad shoulders who are willing to lift people up and act.   Someone asked me recently what I would tell Dr. King if he were here today. After giving my thanks for all he did, I would tell him that the work and action continues every single day. The challenges haven’t diminished our spirit. The opposition hasn’t weakened us. His vision and his dream continue to nurture and guide us.

The Statue of Liberty famously reads, "give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free." It's an inscription that reminds us of the values and ideals our democracy was built on, and inspires us to continue fighting for those values every day.  President Trump's executive order goes against those values and greatly threatens our national security. We should be opening our arms to refugees fleeing war-torn countries, regardless of their religion, not banning them. #NoMuslimBan

I was proud to join Senator Tom Carper at the Philadelphia International Airport this afternoon to ensure the wellbeing of all refugees and immigrants who arrived there as well as to stand in solidarity with those protesting President Trump's Executive Order. The President's order has caused chaos and confusion across the country and potentially threatens national security. We will continue fighting in the coming days and weeks to ensure the safety of all Americans as well as those looking for a better life.

Enjoyed participating in U.S. Senator Chris Coons' roundtable discussion about the importance of the Affordable Care Act this morning. We have all acknowledged that there is room to improve the Affordable Care Act to promote access and to drive costs down, but we cannot simply repeal it without a viable replacement plan. The bottom line is that not only will tens of thousands of Delawareans be stripped of their healthcare, but thousands of good-paying jobs will be lost. We have to come together and have an honest conversation, with members of both political parties at the table, about the ways we can improve quality of care and affordability for Delawareans and Americans alike.

Senator Tom Carper, U.S. Senator Chris Coons and I released the following statement about the hostage situation at James T. Vaughn Correctional Center in Smyrna.  “Our hearts are broken for the family and friends of the officer that was killed at the Vaughn Correctional Center earlier this morning. We will keep Steven Floyd in our prayers, and reach out to his loved ones to offer our support. Today is a day of mourning for all of Delaware.  “Our thoughts are with the correctional officers who were harmed, and we hope they have a full and speedy recovery. See me. Hear me. I'm here. I have a voice.
There is no better time to be standing up for Delaware.

This weekend, I had the honor of attending a number of events centered around the arts. I want to once again congratulate Kiara Florez from Caesar Rodney High School for winning the Congressional Art Award with her piece "Kitchen Supplies," and for reminding me of the importance of the arts in our lives.    A teacher once asked me, "What do you know about the arts?" What I know is that the arts connect us. They take us to places we've never been, transporting us through time. The arts expose our hidden treasures, our secrets and our sins.  I also know that writing can cause pain. Words strung together in hate can create manifestos, which open ovens filled with families and trees with "Strange Fruit" hanging from them.   Words can heal and wash away pain. Dangling from paper, a poem can make a man weak in the knees. A sonnet can send a girl down the aisle to the altar. And a book can save a generation.   What I know about the arts is that I can't live without them.

Yesterday, I joined the Bipartisan Task Force to Combat the Heroin Epidemic in a hearing on synthetic opioids. In 2015, there were 228 overdose deaths in Delaware. We need to come together across party lines to find a solution to this growing problem.

Yesterday, I spoke on the House Floor for the first time to oppose a resolution that uses the Congressional Review Act to repeal a rule blocking regulatory action to support and improve public education. It’s our responsibility to give states the tools and resources they need to provide the best education they can to every student and to ensure they can implement the bipartisan Every Student Succeed Act. Instead, the majority repealed the rule in a gross abuse of the CRA and in the process cost states time and money in their efforts to compile feedback on the plan.

This was a special moment for me watching Beth Mattey, President of the National Association of School Nurses, deliver an impassioned speech on how the Affordable Care Act impacts children’s health. Beth used to be the school nurse for both of my children, Alyssa and Alex, in Delaware and is taking a leading role in making our country, our state, and my family proud.

Happy to celebrate Black History Month with Governor Carney at the Delaware Public Archives. "We are not just mighty. We are mightier than we have ever been. Right now more people are engaged and that's good for our country."

Yesterday, I joined a bipartisan group of freshman legislators who committed to working across the aisle respectfully. Although we represent a wide variety of views, our primary goal is always to serve the American people with honor and civility.  Civility isn't about the what. We can all disagree on the what. Civility is about the how. It's about our tone, it's about our tenor, it's about the words that we choose to use and it's about respect. If we expect civility from others, including our children, then we need to model it.

President Trump has gone against his newly confirmed Secretary of Education and completely reversed his own campaign pledge to protect the LGBT community by making the disappointing decision to rollback Title IX protections. This decision is deeply disturbing for a variety of reasons, but mostly because it’s a cruel indication that he doesn’t fully understand the issues facing transgender students across the country. This decision will greatly impact their well-being by sending the message that their concerns are irrelevant and emboldening bullies in schools to discriminate against them.  Our transgender population faces unimaginable discrimination and tragically, 40% of transgender adults have attempted suicide with 92% of them attempting suicide before the age of 25. It’s our moral responsibility to do all we can to see to it that these numbers drop. We do that by encouraging transgender students to be their true selves and by promoting fair treatment.  I implore the President to follow the First Lady’s example of wanting to stop bullying by reconsidering this rollback of key protections for transgender students. These young people are just that, people, and they deserve better from their government. I’m going to keep fighting for them even if this administration will not.

Tomorrow, Kerry Orr, will be joining me at President Donald J. Trump's joint address to Congress. The Affordable Care Act saved her life.   I’ve acknowledged that there is room to improve the Affordable Care Act to promote access and to drive costs down, but we cannot simply repeal it without a viable replacement plan. The bottom line is that not only will tens of thousands of Delawareans be stripped of their healthcare, but thousands of good-paying jobs will be lost. Unfortunately, the GOP’s outline is one that they can’t even agree on and will undoubtedly raise the out-of-pocket health care costs of working families. We have to come together and have an honest conversation, with members of both political parties at the table, about the ways we can improve quality of care and affordability for Delawareans and Americans alike. I will not abandon my convictions or play politics with the lives of my constituents because the truth is, for Kerry and so many other Delawareans, this is a life or death situation and I hope that President Trump as well as my GOP colleagues in Congress realize just how dangerous repealing the Affordable Care Act would be.

President Trump’s executive order erasing critical steps taken to reverse the impacts of climate change on our environment is deeply concerning. We must ensure we are taking every necessary step we can to leave behind a healthy environment for our children to build careers and their own families in. That means we have to protect access to clean air and water, not threaten it under the false premise that the Clean Power Plan is solely to blame for lost jobs in coal country – a notion that even Sen. Mitch McConnell rejects. Instead of backtracking and undermining the progress we’ve made, we have to work toward a clean energy future that not only promotes public health, but also creates good-paying, clean energy jobs. We owe it not only to the future generations of Americans, but to the future generations of global citizens who will face the consequences of the actions we take today.

I'm proud to be an original cosponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act. Pay inequity doesn't just impact women, it impacts our children, our families, and our economy as a whole. It's time to finally put an end to the wage gap.

As a single mom trying to give her kids every opportunity to succeed, I often found myself struggling to pay my bills on time while ensuring that my children were safe and secure.  The sad truth is that as an African American woman, I was more at risk because African American women and Hispanic women make even less than 80 cents to the dollar. That’s why one of my top priorities as a new Member of Congress is to be as strong an advocate for paycheck fairness as my colleagues Rep. Rosa DeLauro and Sen. Patty Murray have been.  The fact that in 2017, we are still demanding women are paid equal to men is astonishing, not just because promoting equality is a no-brainer, but because this isn’t an issue that only affects women. It affects our children, our families and our economy as a whole. In Delaware alone, 49,000 families rely solely on women’s wages to support themselves. The time to act is now. Our families and our future success depend on it.

Attacks on innocent civilians through the use of chemical weapons in Syria have shocked the conscience of us all. President Assad has continued to delegitimize his position and violate the trust of the global community by using heinous tactics against his own people, and we must be steadfast in our efforts to stop innocent lives from being lost. The military strike President Trump authorized last night appears to be an indication of the administration's commitment to standing up and speaking out about this humanitarian crisis, but I fear that we do not have a long-term plan to combat the crisis in Syria. I’m grateful for the work and collaboration from the Todmorden Foundation, the Woodlawn Trustees and HDC MidAtlantic. Their dedication to an important part of our city is critical to creating safe, thriving communities and helps carry out the legacy of William P. Bancroft.

Members of Congress have the opportunity to send a message to LGBTQ people everywhere that their lives are valued and that anything less than full equality will not be tolerated, and I’m going to fight to ensure that message is heard loud and clear. It’s time for the Equality Act to become law.

Providing a quick update minutes before the health care vote.

Today, the House of Representatives voted, with no Democratic support, to pass the American Health Care Act despite not having a Congressional Budget Office (CBO) analysis or any hearings.  My colleagues in the Democratic Caucus have all acknowledged that the Affordable Care Act is not perfect, but we’ve focused on working to improve it instead of tearing healthcare away from millions of Americans and tens of thousands of Delawareans. When I took my oath of office, I became the first person of color to ever represent the state of Delaware in Congress. That day, I carried a scarf that my sister made for me. The scarf was of a print she found when studying our family history. My great-great-great grandfather, a former slave, had signed the document with an ‘X’ to vote in Georgia during the Reconstruction Era. He couldn’t sign his full name, he could only sign an ‘X.’   Standing there, taking my oath of office with the scarf in my hand and recognizing that my election represented where we came from, I realized that change is possible. But change is only possible if we are willing to recognize and see each other as humans, as neighbors, as Americans.   Over the last few days, we’ve seen history repeat itself – race riots broke out in Charlottesville and our president not only failed to denounce and condemn white supremacy, he doubled down on his view that the blame falls on both sides. We’ve seen the leader of our great nation give license to violence and hate. He has signaled to the ‘alt-right’ movement that they are empowered to continue in pursuit of their cause to wipe out those who look, pray, and love differently than them.   The events that occurred in Charlottesville are indicative of a larger divide in our country. This is a seminal moment in our history – one where our president and our elected leaders can unite behind a message of peace and justice and be role models for positive progress. It is our responsibility to honor our history, not only cherish it. It is our responsibility to recognize the mistakes of our past and to be courageous enough to ensure we never repeat them.   The people who stood up and spoke out to help my great-great-great grandfather finally get his right to vote, prevailed. They understood that progress wasn’t inevitable. They understood that it required a concerted effort in pursuit of justice. And today, as Heather Heyer’s family and friends mourn her loss, it’s paramount that we honor her memory, the fortitude of those who stood alongside her, and the memory of our ancestors by recommitting to that same pursuit of justice.    If you believe you would have stood up and fought against oppression, whether you would have marched with Dr. King or if you would have given safe-haven to Jews fleeing the Nazi’s –  stand up now, march now, create safe spaces now. Our freedom depends on it.
